content:
The Act may be cited as the "Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act". The Congress finds that in the 10 years from 1987 through 1996, nearly 2,200 children aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings in the United States. The country leads the industrialized world in rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death. A 1997 CDC study found that the US had a 9 times higher rate of unintentional firearms-related deaths for children under 15 compared to 25 other industrialized countries. Additionally, nearly 8 times as many children are treated annually in US hospitals for nonfatal unintentional gunshot wounds. A study in medical journals found that unintentional gunshot wounds among children often involve handguns, with children as young as 3 years old capable of firing most commercially available handguns. Children as young as 3 years old are strong enough to fire most commercially available handguns, with 25% of 3- to 4-year-olds and 70% of 5- to 6-year-olds having sufficient finger strength. Firearms in the US are not subject to minimum safety standards, as highlighted in a 1997 public opinion poll. The University of Chicago and Johns Hopkins Center found that 74% of Americans support safety regulations for the firearms industry. Many trigger locks are inadequate in preventing accidental discharge or children accessing firearms. Regulation of handgun discharge protection products. The Secretary of the Treasury will regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children from unintentional discharge. Minimum safety standards will be set for these products. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish safety standards for handgun discharge protection products to prevent children from operating a handgun. The standard will ensure that the product is permanently installed and cannot be removed without specific access methods provided by the manufacturer. The Secretary will establish safety standards for handgun discharge protection products to prevent children from operating a handgun. The standard will ensure that the product is permanently installed and cannot be removed without specific access methods provided by the manufacturer. The Secretary will consider using poison prevention packaging test protocols in developing the standard and must issue the final standard within 12 months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will issue the final standard for handgun discharge protection products within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The standard will take effect 6 months after issuance. SEC. 4. ORDERS; INSPECTIONS. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of a handgun discharge protection product that violates the Act. They can also require the recall, repair, or replacement of such products. The Secretary can issue orders to address violations of the Act, including providing notice of risks associated with the product and bringing it into conformity with regulations. The Secretary can issue orders to address violations of the Act, including bringing the product into conformity with regulations, repairing or replacing the product, refunding the purchase price, recalling the product, or submitting a plan for implementation. The Secretary may inspect places where handgun discharge protection products are manufactured, stored, or transported for commercial purposes to ensure compliance with the Act and its regulations. SEC. 5. UNLAWFUL ACTS. Beginning 30 days after a final standard is issued under section 3(b), it will be illegal for licensed manufacturers or importers to sell handguns without a handgun discharge protection product that meets the standard. Licensed dealers are also prohibited from selling handguns without the required protection product supplied by the manufacturer or importer. An exception is made for sales to government departments or agencies. Licensed manufacturers or importers must include a handgun discharge protection product with all handgun sales, except when selling to government departments or agencies. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. Inclusion of Warning Labels In Handgun Packaging. A licensed manufacturer, importer, or dealer must display a warning label on handgun packaging and materials. The label must contain a specific statement in conspicuous and legible type. The label on handgun packaging must contain a statement warning that children can operate handguns, leading to severe injuries or death. It advises keeping handguns locked and unloaded to prevent child access. The warning label on handgun packaging must be visually distinct from other printed matter, similar to regulations in effect as of January 1, 1998. Handguns cannot be sold without accompanying packaging or descriptive materials. The dealer must not sell a handgun without proper packaging or descriptive materials, unless the required label is affixed as prescribed by the Secretary. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.

Licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers must report any information indicating a child's unintentional or self-inflicted gunshot wound from a handgun they sold after the Act's effective date, resulting in death, serious injury, or medical treatment.

SEC. 8. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary can impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for each violation of the Act and revoke a federal firearms license for violations. Additionally, individuals affected by violations have the right to pursue legal action. Private Cause of Action: Any person aggrieved by a violation of the Act or its regulations can sue for damages in a US district court, with the possibility of receiving attorney's fees. This remedy is in addition to other available remedies. Private enforcement of the Act allows any interested person to bring a lawsuit in a US district court to enforce the Act or restrain violations. The court may award attorney's fees to a prevailing plaintiff. Compliance with the Act is not a requirement for pursuing legal action. Private enforcement of the Act allows any interested person to bring a lawsuit in a US district court to enforce the Act or restrain violations. The court may award attorney's fees to a prevailing plaintiff. Compliance with the Act or any order issued under it does not exempt anyone from liability under common law or State statutory law. The failure of the Secretary to take action authorized by the Act is not admissible in litigation related to the product under common law or State statutory law. Criminal penalties may be imposed on any person who has received benefits from the Act. Criminal penalties may be imposed on any person who violates a provision of the Act with respect to a handgun discharge protection product, including fines and imprisonment for up to 2 years. SEC. 9. NO EFFECT ON STATE LAW. This Act does not affect State laws unless they conflict with this Act, and State laws providing greater protection to children regarding handguns are not considered inconsistent. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms such as "handgun discharge protection product," "children," "licensed importer," "licensed manufacturer," "licensed dealer," "Secretary," and "handgun" as per section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code.
